G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: This is a civil action for breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14.

G.L. c. 239.proposition: Defendant Thomas B. Mitchell is an individual and the owner and/or manager of the residential rental property located at 123 Main Street, Chelsea, Massachusetts 02150 (the “Property”), who at all relevant times has been Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of G.L. c. 186 and G.L. c. 239.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in the Chelsea Division of the District Court Department pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1 and applicable court rules because the rental premises are situated within this Court’s territorial jurisdiction and the Defendant transacts business there.

G.L. c. 239, \u00a7 8A.proposition: Defendant, as Plaintiff’s landlord, had an obligation, arising from statute and common law, to maintain the common areas, including the main entrance and door lock, in a reasonably safe, secure, and habitable condition. See G.L. c. 186, § 14; G.L. c. 239, § 8A; *Hemingway*, 363 Mass. at 199–203.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants not only against formal evictions, but also against serious, substantial, and unreasonable interferences with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, including conditions in the common areas and building systems that materially affect habitability or safety.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The court undertakes an extended discussion of the statutory and common‑law covenant of quiet enjoyment, explaining that it protects tenants against serious interferences with the tenancy and that liability does not require malicious intent. The interference here consisted of repeated flooding from building systems and porous basement walls—conditions relating to habitability and sanitation, not formal eviction—yet the court holds this can constitute interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. This squarely supports the proposition that the covenant reaches serious, substantial, and unreasonable interferences, including building and common‑area conditions affecting habitability or safety.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’… Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy…. When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute… [Gem] violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants not only against formal evictions, but also against serious, substantial, and unreasonable interferences with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, including conditions in the common areas and building systems that materially affect habitability or safety.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The decision holds that a landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached not only by formal eviction, but by serious, substantial, and unreasonable interferences—here, extreme late‑night noise from a commercial tenant—that render the premises not reasonably habitable. The court emphasizes that liability can arise from conditions that are the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, and explicitly notes that the landlords may not collect rent for premises that are not reasonably habitable. This aligns with recognizing quiet enjoyment as protecting against substantial interferences with use, habitability, and safety beyond formal eviction.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done…. Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants not only against formal evictions, but also against serious, substantial, and unreasonable interferences with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, including conditions in the common areas and building systems that materially affect habitability or safety.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion is primarily about whether a lead paint statute violation automatically constitutes a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, and it holds that some degree of landlord fault (at least negligence with notice) is required. In doing so, however, the court expressly relies on prior quiet-enjoyment cases involving defects and habitability problems (e.g., failure to repair leaky roofs or bring apartments into habitable condition) as recognized violations of § 14. That discussion affirms that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants from serious, substantial interferences with use and enjoyment arising from conditions in the premises and building systems that materially affect habitability or safety, not just from formal evictions, though this case itself concerns a private unit condition rather than common areas specifically.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). … [I]n each case since the 1973 statutory revision in which we have recognized a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, there was evidence that the landlord failed to act reasonably in the circumstances concerning a problem known to the landlord, and the natural and probable consequences of such failure caused the interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.

*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants not only against formal evictions, but also against serious, substantial, and unreasonable interferences with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, including conditions in the common areas and building systems that materially affect habitability or safety.
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.support_reasoning: The court squarely applies the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment to serious, substantial, and unreasonable interferences with tenants’ use and enjoyment of their premises, specifically including loss of use of external common areas controlled by the landlord. It holds that pervasive criminal activity in those common areas, if left unaddressed by the landlord, can constitute a breach because it seriously interferes with tenants’ ability to use sidewalks, streets, parking lots and recreation areas. This directly supports the proposition that Massachusetts courts recognize quiet enjoyment as protecting against more than formal evictions, extending to conditions in common areas that materially affect habitability or safety.
*Doe v. New Bedford Housing Auth.*, 417.relevant_excerpt:
“The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold….

In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises…. If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

*Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 782.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants not only against formal evictions, but also against serious, substantial, and unreasonable interferences with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, including conditions in the common areas and building systems that materially affect habitability or safety.
*Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 782.support_reasoning: The opinion directly interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment) and holds that a landlord’s omissions, including failure to repair substantial sanitary, building, and fire code violations, can constitute a breach where they substantially impair the value of the leased premises. The Court emphasizes that liability turns on the landlord’s conduct, not intent, and applies § 14 to serious conditions—lack of heat and hot water, vermin infestation, defective smoke detector, windows, wiring, and no fire escape—that materially affect habitability and safety, including common areas, thereby aligning with the stated proposition.
*Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 782.relevant_excerpt: “In Ianello v. Court Management Corp., 400 Mass. 321, 323 (1987), it was said that a landlord violates § 14 when his acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises.… A landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.… Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations… includ[ing] inadequate heat and hot water and a serious infestation of vermin… [which] would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place… On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Massachusetts courts have recognized that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects tenants not only against formal evictions, but also against serious, substantial, and unreasonable interferences with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, including conditions in the common areas and building systems that materially affect habitability or safety.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on the implied warranty of habitability and rent abatement, not on the covenant of quiet enjoyment. While it does recognize that failures in building systems such as heat and hot water can be material breaches of the warranty of habitability, it does not analyze or discuss the scope of the covenant of quiet enjoyment or its application to serious interferences in common areas or building systems. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific quiet-enjoyment proposition stated, even though the factual context overlaps with habitability and safety concerns.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “Furthermore, Berman contends, the purpose of the warranty is ‘to provide tenants with a mechanism to encourage the repair of serious and dangerous defects’ connected with a residential dwelling unit or the common areas. This purpose can be achieved without imposing strict liability on landlords. … The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for.” (379 Mass. at 200-202).

Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); G. L. c. 186, § 14. We have interpreted this obligation to mean that the covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant from serious interference with her tenancy.
